w:r.w:t: Edit this document to make it better.

This document is for people who are building things to influence the 2017 General Election, or thinking about doing so. It’s a collection of resources, datasets, volunteers, existing projects and proposed projects. There is a lot here - take time to sit and read through it - you may find a great collaborator, or resources that make your project much easier to build.
, and assembled with the help of
- big crowdsourced collection of all kinds of relevant datasets.
- If you want to keep up with what’s going on here, and the other people using this document!
- want to do something but don’t know what? add yourself!
How to make a difference in the election:
How to handle collected user data for a project like this:
(add yours - and read over the rest)
Project description / Mission Statement / Help required / Resources offered
Datasmoothie: Create a data-story from Electoral Commission data on donations

We're uploading data on party donations from the Electoral Commission as fast as they publish it to allow anyone, regardless of tech know-how, to crunch the numbers and publish their "data stories" (for free). Click the link on the left to start crunching. Here's an example of what can be done:
The General Election 2017: Who is funding the parties?
Free, open database of UK election candidates (not just at GE...always!) — and
here. Want to run stuff across multiple elections? Use our
) lets you check your MP's voting record
) helps you identify your representative and contact them.
is both accessible and useable. Most of the data is already public, but this project is about ensuring that it is exposed in a better and richer way.”
(help, support, queries for our API and myore)
Open polling data, direct representation, building a relationship with representatives which goes beyond the election.
OpenSurveys for polling that you can embed on your website
Also open API, and embeddable question sets - https://represent.me/2017/04/20/using-the-represent-api-for-ge2017/

Represent are working with UK Parliament to create accessible versions (plain English summaries, key questions & API for both) of proposed laws and present them as a series of straightforward questions which anyone can vote on and embed anywhere. Also pushing votes via chatbot. Voters have a unique profile, allowing us to analyse and publish results and trends. We send constituency and national results to each MP and to journalists. We notify individuals how their MP voted, and how they compare. Seeking partners for this! We think this is going to be very powerful for interest orgs and civic society since it will also include vote delegation (liquid democracy style) thus amplifying voter power.
making some easy tools for people to use, eg
gives ward, constituency, ref result, current MP, previous party (if different), if they’re leaving or under investigation. Just put the postcode at the end. Also full record of last election
for usage info. *Includes referendum data and MP twitter handles* Other tools to come.
Twitter tools to send tweets to candidates, election version of tweetyourMP.com (will publish source code if you want to put together your own version)

We’re working out which demographics campaigns are targeting and what messages they’re using in their communication. We’ve developed a browser extension that detects campaign ads shown to you on facebook and keeps a tally of who’s advertising the most. We’re aggregating the data to build maps of where specific campaigns are targeting.
Possible scope to use the data as evidence in a campaign for electoral spending / Facebook transparency reform. Please get in touch if the legal side of this excites you!

French civic tech, social network dedicated to politics with a ranking system for the ideas. National and local levels. Offers services to elected representatives. Not in English yet but looking for help
Many people do not realise homeless people are eligible to vote, we are here to change that.

Many constituencies are highly marginal with a slim majority of only a few hundred votes, in these constituencies every vote counts. In most of these seats the homeless population are many times greater than the margin of victory in the 2015 general election.
The homeless vote genuinely has the potential to be the decisive vote in this year’s election.

to be a step by step guide on how get homeless people registered by May 22nd in each of the top 30 marginal constituencies (focussed on these due to time constraints of a snap election). We still need data for most constituencies and to spread the word. To get involved and help empower the homeless voice email
provides an interactive way to explore the way in which Members of the UK parliament use the social media website Twitter.
Creating 650 Twitter lists, each of which will contain the candidates for a constituency (using Democracy Club data to build these lists). Allowing people to easily follow their local candidates.
Write to your GE candidates about corruption
I’m looking to embed a form into our website that will allow visitors to write directly to their local GE candidates – using a suggested text – without leaving the page.
Facebook bot for candidate and manifesto information
I’d welcome any suggestions or advice!
Analyse Tweets from MPs for sentiment and patterns

MPs from the top 5 parties have tweeted a staggering xxx tweets since the GE was called on Apr 18th. @stevebeasant is the standout contributor with over 3,000. Using the TextBlob classifier, over 99% of tweets have neither positive or negative sentiment!

In the build up to the election, journalists will be using Krzana for free to monitor discussions by and about every political candidate on any topic, across 60,000 handpicked sources, from social media and blogs to local and national press. Other topics such as voter intimidation can also be looked into through the same platform.
Predict who will win the most votes in the UK General Election for a chance to win a £20 Amazon voucher and bragging rights.
Processing/filtering of results from 2015, with visualisation per constituency, region, overall results with impact of swing. From #ge2107 hackathon.

Looks at the ‘power’ of individual votes by constituency. Lots of info-graphics. Has (imho) a flawed approach, suggesting that vote power only relates to ‘winning’ - that a vote for a narrowly defeated candidate is a ‘wasted’ vote. Interesting nonetheless.

Crowdfunder are actively supporting pro-democracy projects for the general election (short turn around, donations only / no rewards, ‘keep what you raise’) . A number of the projects here are running a campaign now and it’s worth considering.
is a good contact to start with or go to their GE2017 page:

Freshly assembled group of data scientists, software engineers & political operatives. Our goal is to understand why forecasting elections in the UK using open data is notoriously difficult, and to see how far good statistical practice and modern machine learning methods can take us. Inspired by FiveThirtyEight. If you’re interested in joining us and helping out please get in touch via @SixFiftyData or @john_sandall!
We built Jeremy Corbyn’s website when he was our local MP and his team got in touch with us to redo the homepage for the election so that it was more in keeping with the Labour site.
Enter your postcode to find your nearest marginal and a list of canvassing sessions happening near you. There's also the option to join a carpool and meet other activists on the way!
Contact @benjaminhowarth for Lib Dem digital project, expertise in data science and social media particularly appreciated
‘new political party’ - previously creating an open manifesto
or search “corbyn run” on the app store(s)
8-bit political satire game which communicates the labour manifesto in an easily digestible way to young potential voters
Promoting GOTV via viral WhatsApp messaging:

surfacing ads or promoting posts containing a link which points to getoutandvote.co.uk which then runs a script to open WA, select contacts and push a pre populated message including the original link to the webpage (and wheredoivote etc) - (
supporting candidates who share values of opportunity, tolerance, democracy, environment and openness.
Pairs of voters collaborate to minimise wasted votes (available to all major parties).
API available for vote recommendation sites to prepolulate a swap, making voter journey more frictionless -
progressive alliance organising & funding & tactical voting tool
Not relaunching for 2017 - see Swap my Vote
To mobilise/coordinate people who want to stop Conservative govt but aren’t necessarily party activists. Identifies and targets marginal seats.
A play with data from last election
Simple postcode lookup which returns the name of the anti-Brexit candidate on your seat.
Gently encouraging people to make their vote count

Non-partisan tactical voting recommendation web site. Provides a simple recommendation to users for their seat, allows easy sharing. Works behind the scenes to ensure we do not split the vote and the message reaches largest possible audience. For June 8th 2017 election, 2.6m visitors, 650k visitors in final 48 hours. Offers open data.
How should I vote to stop a destructive Brexit?
Organizing leafleting and ground campaigns; local campaign lead volunteers needed.
With multiple landing pages driven from multiple advertising themes on Facebook

For the 2015 election, the 50:50 Parliament campaign compiled a list of “Ones to Watch” - constituencies where there was a chance of gaining a new woman MP. It used three datasets: a list of all candidates, a list of all existing MPs, and a list of all MPs who were standing down. It was cobbled together in Excel quite last minute and was far from perfect.

It would be great to do something similar/better, and do it sooner, to support the 50:50 #AskHerToStand campaign, which is supporting women to become MPs. We don’t have the skills to do this, other than repeating the error-prone and hard work approach in Excel. A couple of days of somebody with data skills would be appreciated!
Get anonymously connected to a random person with opposing views on facebook messenger!

Towards developing a loosely coherent and dynamic social media strategy that empowers us all as dispersed but similarly motivated individuals and groups to utilise the communication infrastructure available. Enable the tens of thousands of active social media users to communicate beyond their own social media echo chambers/friend bubbles. Potential to use it to help organise concerted efforts to aid various aspects of campaigning, and effectively spread a progressive message to reach as many people as possible.
Our mission is to empower young citizens to lead the change that they want to see within society
Represent is an online voting platform. You answer questions, we make sure that decision-makers want to listen. #JointheHeard #RepresentMel,
reminders to vote and (hopefully) directions to polling booths (via Democracy Club)
An online education platform teaching people how to do politics (voting, electioneering, community organising, digital campaigning, etc) (This is a project by The Fourth Group

Joint project by ACORN #RentersRising, Generation Rent, Renters Power Project and others, launching soon. Registering and getting out the powerful renters vote and demanding policies for renters. Contact

We are a youth democratic education organisation. We are spearheading a project with other youth citizenship organisations to get resources and information to teachers and schools to support registration/education on GE2017.

We are campaigning for as many people as possible to take part in the UK General Election on June 8th. Our aim is to share statements from people like you about why your vote is important, so everyone is inspired to get involved.
Our mission is to empower young citizens to lead the change that they want to see within society
Hack the vote is a volunteer group building technology to increase voter turnout in the 2017 general election.
Ben & Jerry’s - get out the youth vote
Ben & Jerry’s has teamed up with HOPE not hate to launch ‘Don’t Get Frozen Out’, a campaign encouraging Londoners to register to vote ahead of the Mayoral Election on May 5th 2016.

We need a democracy where all voices are heard, one where we can all have an equal say over the decisions that affect our capital! Register to vote by 18th April 2016 and make sure your voice is counted!
We offer a platform for young people to voice their opinions and a variety of tools, workshops and courses to empower schools in being able to give students practical Political Literacy education.
Full list of 19 different VAAs from 2015
(most have not yet announced if they’re going to do versions for this election yet)
Purpose: a non-partisan service to help more people vote, and make an informed decision
What is does: enables a direct comparison of each party’s manifesto policies (but without knowing which party they belong to).

Impact: Just under 1 million users in 2015. A national poll found that 35% users were more likely to vote after using this format (the rest ‘as likely’ to vote). This means, the more people that use Vote for Policies, the more people will vote. Hence, we need scale!
Integrates with: Democracy Club’s WhoCanIVoteFor, MySociety’s TheyworkForYou
explore where you stand, see views from all sides and live your values via buy, vote and campaign matches. Developing Election 2017 VAA
Purpose: vote on issues you care about. Find out how you compare to parties, candidates and others. The data will be used to help you hold MPs to account once elected from June 9.
New tool launching soon - Take the political matchmaker test, see where you stand, match with campaigns, candidates and help crowdfund and support the change the candidates that align with you.
A tool to help voters generate a pre-filled postal voting form, ready to send to their local authority
A map and addresses of all of the places people can access the internet for free and get assisted digital support to register to vote

The UK's independent non partisan factchecking charity. Will be fact checking campaign claims like we did for EU referendum and GE15. We can also confirm that we’ll be using our automated factchecking tools this election! Exciting eh?
assisted fact checking for claims about economic statistics (unemployment, immigration etc). For the people!
building a not-for-profit Voter Advice Application, in collaboration with previous VAA creators like TickBox, LeaveOrStay etc.
hopefully going to collect a data set of the promises made by main parties in the run up to the election. Will be manifesto centred and non-partisan

General Election 2017 sees the first installment of Pop-Up Newsroom - a from scratch, digital-first experimental newsroom colocating student journalists and newsroom product teams working together with the goal of establishing new best practices, workflows & tools! By DigDeeper Media & Meedan, supported by the First Draft Partner Network and powered by Google News Lab.
Political Twitter Bots, and other political campaigning/propaganda tools “
We work with data, disruptive technologies, maths and visual art to explore questions”

Tool that makes gov formula on school cuts transparent, and shows what they mean for the 93% of cuts that schools will receive. User journey: search postcode/school → budget breakdown, /pupil and /teacher shown on individual school card for the 93% of schools that will receive cuts.

During the election, the NUT worked out what Con, Lab & Lib Dem manifesto commitments meant for school budgets, and we used the Democracy Club DB to allow people to send an email to the candidates of their constituency requesting that they pledge to fight the school cuts. The result was displayed with a tick, X or ? and pledges so far were displayed in a party % breakdown on the homepage.
Over 1 million hits since we launched in Nov 16, and over 2.8 million schools searched in month up to election. Landmark election campaigning tool and referenced by Chris Cook lots.

Similar idea to School Cuts, we found that a lot of the well known NHS stats were missing a few big facts. We built this to allow people to check data for hospitals and GP surgeries across the UK including how long it takes to see a DR/GP, and waiting times for operations.

A site based on facts, past votes and policies from Con and Lab. User swipes left for JC and Labour, and right for ™ & Tories to show info on a range of manifesto areas such as Brexit, NHS, defence, immigration and housing. Built in less than a week in an attempt to provide alternative to mainstream media bias.
Ideas (not projects) with no real idea how to execute:
give citizens a quick run down of how to pop up their own campaign if needed (message, money, mobilisation). What can an individual or group achieve in a few hours?
identifies potential swing seats and provides tools to lobby people in your social circle. London / cities with multiple constituencies only? E.g. this snippet from the FT:
I think a powerful new medium for communication is the visual essay. Something like this:
I’ll give it a go on my own but it is a lot of work. If someone reading this has experience with front-end dev / D3.js and would like to collaborate, then give me a shout
Bit like Tinder.. List of questions to ask the various parties..MPs/ Canvassers- you can write their response.

Idea for events campaign asking folk to host online events to meet and go vote together, invite friends to RSVP and pledge to vote so can then chase them up and make sure they come. Make as fun/creative as like; “polls then pub”, “polls then party” etc. Idea is to overcome “just got in from work” inertia and get out the vote. Contact
to help implement, we want partners! :)
Votebuddy will be a tactical voting app. Where people who has same affiliations help eachother to make sure that they vote in the elections that matters to them.

The votebuddy will alert people know about the main elections happening in their areas, states, countries where they can vote. It will give them location, date and time where they can vote. Register link for voting if they haven’t done it. Send them reminder about the voteday, give them map with how to reach to the voting station. If for some reason, they can’t go they can ask one of their vote buddies to help them to reach to the polling stations (i.e. rideshare etc).
Hi all, if you think this can be useful for voters to help them make rational decision please contact me at daniel@wikibudgets.org
